ld be standard engineering practices are neither practiced nor

This is a great discussion and I've been enjoying following=
 along.

In the (somewhere in the region north of) ten years that I've been=
 using
JUnit, I have never had their use mandated *and* enforced by an empl=
oyer
and
I've never been asked about them in an interview.

I just applied =
for a developer position at nearby big city and had to
complete a pre-scree=
ning call technical questionnaire and some of the
Java
questions included "=
write a method that does X", but no mention of JUnit
(or
any other such too=
l). So, I threw caution to the wind and submitted not
only
methods that did=
 X, but unit tests to ensure that the method really did
do
my best understa=
nding of X.

Two of my three previous employers had zero unit tests in-hous=
e when I
stepped through the door. In both of them, I wrote the first tests=
 and
started trying to share the vision of tested code being somewhere that=

bugs
can't hide. It's hard work.

Unit testing should be a "no-brainer", b=
ut I find that it's still
treated
poorly within corporations.

Simon
